title: مُرَاجَعَةٌ
description: Comprehensive review of fundamental concepts from Books 1 and 2 before advancing to derived forms.

notes.title: Declension of Nouns (الإعراب)
content: Declinable nouns indicate their grammatical function by their endings (علامات الإعراب). Understanding these endings is fundamental to reading and writing Arabic correctly.
The three primary cases are: nominative (الرفع) marked by dammah, accusative (النصب) marked by fathah, and genitive (الجر) marked by kasrah.
keyPoints: Dammah (ـُ) indicates nominative case - the noun is مرفوع
Fathah (ـَ) indicates accusative case - the noun is منصوب
Kasrah (ـِ) indicates genitive case - the noun is مجرور

examples.english: This is the teacher's car (genitive - possessive)

notes.title: Secondary Endings
content: Certain noun groups use secondary endings instead of the primary ones. These include the sound feminine plural, diptotes, the five nouns, sound masculine plural, and dual nouns.
keyPoints: Sound feminine plural: nasb takes kasrah instead of fathah
Diptotes: jarr takes fathah instead of kasrah
The five nouns use waw for raf', alif for nasb, and ya' for jarr
Sound masculine plural ends with -ūna (raf') and -īna (nasb/jarr)

notes.title: Moods of Verbs
content: Arabic verbs have three forms: māḍī (past), muḍāri' (present/future), and amr (imperative). The māḍī and amr are mabnī (fixed endings), while the muḍāri' is mu'rab (endings change).
The muḍāri' has three moods: marfū' (indicative) with -u ending, manṣūb (subjunctive) with -a ending, and majzūm (jussive) where the ending is dropped or changed.
